title: Solar Frontier Aims for Global Market From Tohoku Plant (2)
text:
Solar Frontier Aims for Global Market From Tohoku Plant (2) Solar Frontier Aims for Global Market From Tohoku Plant (2) Responds to local needs and steadily gains ground in the US, Europe and Middle East 2015/09/20 14:23 
Continued from Solar Frontier Aims for Global Market From Tohoku Plant (1) Sale of sets with storage batteries is common in Germany 
In the European Market, Solar Frontier works out sales strategies responding to the renewable energy policy of each country. 
In Germany, Spain and Italy, which introduced the feed-in tariff (FIT) scheme earlier than other countries and led the solar power generation market in Europe, introduction of compact equipment for self-consumption has been accelerating following the decline in purchase price. 
"In Germany, in particular, an increasing number of houses are introducing self-sufficient systems where batteries are installed in basements for storage of solar power," Gakumazawa said. 
Solar Frontier Europe, a subsidiary based in Germany, focuses on these markets and has been selling the "power set," a system consisting of solar panels, storage batteries, a monitor and a PV inverter that controls them, for use mainly in houses. The output of solar panels and the capacity of storage batteries can be selected from 10 patterns of combinations. 
Responding to the increasing needs for self-consumption systems intended for small offices, this spring, the company commercialized "Power Set Industrial." Solar panel output is limited to two patterns of units – 21kW and 33kW – to enhance the cost performance of systems. 
"If the two types of units are combined, it will be possible to respond to the needs for more than 100kW," Gakumazawa said. "They are more popular than we had expected because the product comes in two patterns and are simple." 
Meanwhile, the UK has introduced the RPS system, and, in the same manner as the US, construction plans of mega solar power plants are based on BOT. Based on this background, Solar Frontier Europe signed contracts for development and sale of solar power plants with a total output of up to 100MW in the UK, in collaboration with German renewable energy developer New Energy for the World (NEW). The solar power plants will incorporate panels manufactured by Solar Frontier. 
In 2014, Solar Frontier and NEW jointly developed a 7.2MW mega solar power plant incorporating CIS-based solar panels in Banwell in the southeast of the UK (Fig. 5). According to Solar Frontier, the result was highly valued and led to the joint development of 100MW facilities. Fig. 5: The "Banwell Solar Project," a 7.2MW project in Banwell in the UK (source: Solar Frontier)
